Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List:
4 hours for readings weeks

2 hours per week

Weeks with essays due: 15-20
Week with presentation: 13
Final paper: 25
3-5 hours depending on the reading
dense readings, could take 4-6 hours
3 generally, 10-15 hrs for assignments
2 hours a week for readings, 5+ hours when assignments were due

Overall I really enjoyed this class. I felt it was thought-provoking, engaging and the right level of work. I really enjoyed the short student presentations. They really introduced me to so many new thoughts and ideas about various areas of mental health.

strengths: given the sensitive nature of the material a main strength is the well-established friendliness and sensitivity of the classroom environment. 
weaknesses: addressing the differences between epi of mental illness and more familiar content like epi of the flu or epi of cancer explicitly at the beginning of the course would helped frame the issues better.
This course is really interesting. Its strengths are that it allowed an open dialogue amongst students and the information was presented in a really useful way.
I loved everything about this course. Exactly what a graduate school class should be, and how I wish all of my classes at YSPH could be taught. Outstanding, truly.
This is my favorite class so far, I really enjoyed learning about all the factors regarding mental health. And also really enjoyed the assignments and presentations.

The lectures in the course were rich and purposeful. It would have been nice to see more discussion of the concepts as opposed to just Q&A style learning from the professor. However, even the Q&A was engaging. The weekly student presentations were a unique and fun way to learn about other topics, of interest sot the student sand related to the course. i think they were a great way to diversify the subject matter.
Great class, but sometimes felt that not everything was being covered because of having to get through student presentations.

Megan Smith has an extremely relevant and experienced perspective - I learned so much from her thoughtfully planned out course
Each class left time at the end for several student presentations. Due to the class size, presentations were limited to 3 minutes, which was very difficult to make and also to pay attention to due to the rapid nature of the presentation. This ended up taking almost 45 minutes from each class and cut into lecture time. I think I would have appreciated Dr. Smith completing her lectures rather than never getting through the week's material due to student presentations
great survey of mental health issues and the social factors that influence their development and expression
see above

I very much enjoyed this course. Its major strength was the class structure (lecture, presentations, discussion) which kept the 2 hours engaging and interesting. Weekly readings were relevant, discussions were robust, and the workload was manageable.

This course provided a strong base of knowledge in mental health and illness and the ability to consider how population-level factors influence mental health outcomes. I would have liked this course more as a smaller, discussion based course, but overall I enjoyed learning from Megan and from my classmates' weekly presentations and panel discussion questions. The assignments were all very relevant, useful, and interesting to complete, and I left this course with very valuable public health and mental health knowledge and practical skills (e.g. mental health policy brief for the governor elect of CT, short and succinct presentation and panel discussion, mediators/moderators).

Strengths of this course is everything. It provided a basis of how mental health is very much a part of public health research and organizations throughout the US. It helped to identify this topics within mental health from our 4 min presentations from all the students.

Strengths:
-Interesting, engaging, dynamic readings
-Supportive learning environment fostered by the professor and TF
-Assignments that allowed practical application of material
-Reasonable expectations in terms of time needed to complete course material each week

Weaknesses:
-Class size. This is something I've come to see with most YSPH courses due to lack of capping. I think discussions would have functioned better with a smaller class/seminar-style setting (~15-20 students).
-I would have enjoyed a bit more time spent on the lecture/discussion portion of class. While the presentations were an excellent opportunity to learn (and learn from other students), the material presented was sometimes a bit scattered and esoteric. Perhaps instead of having students propose highly specific discussion questions, the time might be better spent addressing how the presentations connected to the course material. I think that was the intention of the assignment, but it occasionally got lost in translation.

The course really helped me to learn the basic concepts of mental health and related factors. The readings were related to the week's topic, the class environment was very interactive, student presentations were contributing to the class. But sometimes the process could be so interactive and it was hard to hear a student who was talking on the other corner of the class, which caused distraction when the conversations took a big part of the lesson.
This was an amazing class with interesting material, and Professor Smith is a fantastic professor!

This course was amazing in providing a linear and engaging story on the impact of social and cultural factors on mental health. The in-class exercises gave some perspective on the stresses and barriers to health that people face. I have absolutely no criticisms of this course.

AP-
Truly the best course I have taken in the MPH program. Best educator (M. Smith) and best TF (A Viera).

Dr. Smith truly understands how to maximize each 2-hr lecture period and structure a course. Course readings were selected very carefully; foundational tools in SBS were built upon throughout the course. As someone entering the course without significant affinity towards SBS courses, I found the principles highly informative, shaping my outlook on life/health and providing material for many wonderful dinner conversations.

While assignments seemed to pile up towards the end, they added much depth to the course, affording opportunity for individual exploration. During weeks when I ran low on time for in-depth exploration of readings, splitting up readings (~60-80pgs/week) amongst 3-4 classmates, with each providing a brief summary, was helpful. Several key readings (Costello, Leventhal, Link/Phelan, Alegria, Luhrman) are referenced many many times throughout the course and having synopses compiled (especially since no electronics are allowed in class) are useful for assignments and class discussions.

Single Weakness: The course was such an overwhelmingly positive experience for me that I hesitate to comment on this. However, I did find that instructions regarding the initial assignments (experiential essay, mental health brief to the governor) were not as clear as they could have been. Simply a more detailed prompt would have ensured that readings/concepts were brought into the the assignments in the manner that was expected.

Great course! Strengths: classes are engaging and professor and TA are both wonderful instructors, students present on a topic of their choice and all presentations were informative, readings and classes are varied and all very interesting. Weakness: fairly large class that made it difficult for discussions sometimes.

Excellent course, I really enjoyed the structure of the class and the mix of lecture and group activities during the course. All of the assignments were fun because students were able to select their own specific topic within broader topics.
Good overview of mental health issues from a public health perspective.  The assignments were well-varied and allowed me to think critically about a few key topics that were of interest to me.

This course is my favorite course I have taken at Yale. It looks at a general overview of different disorders while also diving into the intersectionality of the disorders, all grounded in research. The greatest strength of the class is how Dr. Smith pushes you to find your specific interests in the mental health field. There are many opportunities for one to get involved in areas that are of interest through presentations and research papers. The assessment of the course cannot be separated from the assessment of the teacher because they are so interconnected that makes them inseparable.

Outstanding course, highly recommend.  Mental health considerations touch every corner of public health and having an opportunity to deep-dive into mental health issues was extremely additive to the overall MPH experience

AP Strengths: Taught me how to use the evidence to make policy arguments for public health issues. Would also be useful for areas outside of mental health.
Weaknesses: With a large class, I feel that there were too many individual presentations and the time would be better spent discussing the readings,  possibly these could be done in groups.
Wonderful class!

Strengths: Up-to-date, intersectional, woke
Weaknesses: Not super interactive at times, and it always felt rushed when it was interactive (could very well be due to the size of the class). I wish the final project was a little more creative because it felt more like a lit review. More assignments to engage with the material more would have been nice.

This is a great course from a content perspective. The information is relevant and interesting. However, if you are not in SBS, you may find it more challenging to relate all the information appropriately back to the assignments in the appropriate language.

I thought this course was very interesting, and I learned a lot about the social and cultural determinants of mental health. I think I walked away with a lot more knowledge about various sub-topics within mental health, which was my goal for this course.

Great course that encouraged integration of material during each subsequent class. I had anticipated more of a background into the etiology/epidemiology of the mental illnesses we discussed and would have appreciated more on this side. I think the class became very content heavy towards Indian reservations for some reason and a bit political. For example, we had many readings and discussions on eliminating the wealth gap, Medicaid expansion, handing out cash bonds to minorities, etc., yet I think there is a large deficit (and at many courses at YSPH) acknowledging that these routes are not the only "correct" means of achieving social and cultural sensitivity, particularly if we want to engage both sides of the political spectrum. I would have appreciated a more balanced discussion of these examples.

Great course. Well laid out. Good progression. Fair work load. A lot of readings, but prof is not too much of a stickler on how much you got done. Work is relatable to class discussions and is practical.
Course was fantastic in that it created a safe-space for discussion around sensitive mental health topics.

amazing course on an important topic! I like that there are assessments beyond examinations. Although I left with more exposure on mental health, I wish there were more tangible skills I could have left with.
The topics of this course were very interesting and provide a solid foundation for thinking about the social and cultural factors that relate to different mental health outcomes.

Dr. Smith was an amazing professor. This really wasn't a course I had planned to take but even during shopping week I could tell how passionate she is about the material and how engaging of a professor she is. Dr. Smith is so knowledgable about this work and is so well connected in the field. Her experiences working in this field and enthusiasm about her work and others was inspiring and kept the class buzzing with great discussion.

strengths: dynamic and interested in student input
weaknesses: moves very fast.  sometimes I felt confused about whether we were speaking about population health or individual health.
Megan is a great professor. She offers a lot of insight and is open to hearing about other students' experiences. She creates a great learning environment.
Megan Smith is an absolute GEM -  brilliant, compassionate, and warm. Such a pleasure to learn from. Deeply appreciated her questions, presentations, and feedback!
Professor Smith is an awesome instructor, I really learnt a lot. She would always ask critical questions that encourage use to reflect deeper about certain issues.

Professor Smith is very knowledgeable and passionate about the topics she teaches. She is great at moderating the classroom and connecting questions and answers from students to previous topics covered. Overall, she is great at connecting the dots between different examples and theories covered.
Great professor, fosters a good learning environment. Very intelligent and knows her stuff!
interesting speaker. insightful

Megan is a wonderful instructor. Her lecture style is engaging, her feedback to students' discussion points is encouraging and constructive, and she thoughtfully integrates both the clinical and public health perspectives that students bring to the classroom. One suggestion is more feedback throughout the semester.

Megan is a wonderful professor and is truly engaged and invested in our learning. Her lectures were engaging, fast-paced (in a good way), and relevant to current events (not something you always see at YSPH). She facilitated a positive learning environment by encouraging our questions and helping students think through how to best tackle a question and create an answer/solution.
Amazing instructor. Dr. Smith is innovative in her approach, and holds a wealth of knowledge and experience on the topic.

Megan Smith was a pleasure to get to know and learn from. Her work with the MOMs partnership is very inspiring and the amount of time she poured into us was well received. There was enough engagement and group activities in the class that allowed us all to learn from each other and the instructor.

Megan is wonderful. She fostered an incredibly positive learning environment where students were treated as equal colleagues. This was particularly instrumental for me personally as I don't have a background in medicine or healthcare.

Dr. Smith is a great instructor. She is so enthusiastic and energetic, loves to share and really tries to motivate students to involve the class. Her communication with students was so positive and friendly but was also keeping the respect.

Professor Smith always presented course material in a very engaging way that was both easy to understand and intuitive/innovative for students. She made us think about mental health from different angles and created a very supportive learning environment. She is also a very supportive and kind person which made the class very enjoyable.

Dr. Smith was excellent in every way. She was so warm and gave off an air of compassion and understanding. When people participated in class, she welcomed all answers and when people did not give "correct" answers to questions, she would respectfully give the correct answer while still making them feel like they contributed something to the class.

AP-
Summary: Engaging, thoughtful, well-organized educator. The most well-rounded, insightful educator in my 3.5 years of post-graduate schooling.

1. Carefully selected readings to build upon topics (social causation/selection, compositional/contextual factors, mediators/moderators...) throughout the course, offering concrete tools to my understanding of SBS.
2. Remained very conscientious of timing and respectful of student opinions, inviting a welcoming learning environment. She maintained immense balance in the class in acknowledging each student comment while ensuring that biased/incorrect comments were addressed with grace.
3. Offered many opportunities for individual exploration. Given her wealth of knowledge of the literature, she is an incredible resource for exploring individual topics in mental health, simply reciting relevant authors/studies/journals in response to questions/comments.
4. Truly utilized seminal research to build upon key concepts throughout the course. As a medical student taking the course, I was most interested in obtaining key tools for understanding mental health and SBS; I left the course very pleased with the many tools Prof Smith taught us. She leverages the strengths from her strong research background with her clinical understanding of psychiatry.
I really enjoyed having Dr. Smith teach this class. I thought her powerpoint slides and class lectures were all very engaging! Great instructor overall!

Very knowledgeable and responsive to feedback.  Created a safe environment where students were open to sharing.  Although I loved the class, I think teaching could be improved through better time management - we often did not finish a topic or discussion during class and had to come back to it at the start of the next class.

This instructor is my favorite professor that I have had the pleasure of taking. It is taught by one of the most engaging and thought-provoking teachers. Dr. Smith finds a way to pull in all readings that she assigns, thus making all outside work you do for the class be extremely relevant to that day's lecture. Her knowledge is deep and she shares her expertise with the class/encourages the class to share their experience while making it academic and research-based. The greatest strength of the class is how she pushes you to find your specific interests in the mental health field. There are many opportunities for one to get involved in areas that are of interest through presentations and research papers. The assessment of the course cannot be separated from the assessment of the teacher because they are so interconnected that makes them inseparable.
She is an amazing professor and extremely knowledgeable about the current mental health literature.
One of the best instructors I've had at YSPH.  Dr. Smith's deep understanding and expertise was invaluable to the overall course.
AP: Links the material cohesively together, draws learning points from the class, engaging lecturer. Thoughtful use of media eg documentary footage complemented the in-class material
Very knowledgable and approachable!
Amazing!!

Dr. Smith is a fantastic instructor. She is highly knowledgeable and very up-to-date on the literature. She is very intentional on her approach of offering diverse perspectives which I genuinely appreciate. I had never seen a white professor address colorism and mental health. She is humble and tactful in her approach and never makes someone feel like they answered something wrong.
Weaknesses: None I can think of.
Professor Smith is amazing. She's brilliant and engaging and makes the classes very conversational.

Professor Smith was great. I appreciated the vast amount of knowledge she had about the topics we covered, and I appreciate that she tried to make sure we got all the information that was important for us to know on several of the topics we talked about.
Excellent! Professor Smith was so attuned to considering all aspects of the issues that we discussed and encouraged us all to think analytically and with sensitivity.
Megan is great. A very knowledgeable professor. ONe of the better faculty members at this school.
Dr. Smith brought in lots of personal anecdotes and demonstrated both breadth and depth of expertise in the subject.
Amazing instructor! Professor Smith is engaging, validating and teaches this class with ease. It was wonderful learning from her.
Very knowledgeable and passionate about the subject. Also, a very engaging lecturer-definitely made us think critically during class and in our assignments.

I would highly recommend this course to someone. I learned a lot throughout the semester on a topic I wasn't initially sure I was completely interested in. I have actually been very inspired by this course and hope to apply some of what I learned to my own research. I also think the course work for this class was extremely reasonable while also requiring sufficient thought and effort.

this course takes a more thematic perspective on mental illness than a disease-specific perspective.  This makes it a little difficult to weave concepts together over the term, but serves the purpose of thinking more critically about the issues at play in epi of mental illness.
This course is great. I would recommend it. I enjoyed having no exams and only papers and presentations. It really allowed me to learn in a stress-free environment and then apply my knowledge.

If you are a YSPH student, TAKE THIS COURSE. Grateful to have had the opportunity to have been in a course with such a renowned and compassionate instructor - learned so much and enjoyed every class and assignment. One of the very few YSPH courses I actually enjoyed and felt supported in.

This was a great course to learn the basics of mental health within different social and cultural contexts. It is not very discussion-based but it is rich in material. There are a lot of readings but the readings are very relevant and Professor Smith does a great job at incorporating the readings into the classroom discussion.
I would highly recommend this course to public health students - other public health courses should be modeled like this one.
Great class, reasonable amount of reading. No exams, just a few papers. Highly recommend taking class if interested in mental health
for an SBS mental health class, i thought it would be more fluffy and was not expecting for such an incredibly worthwhile discussion through the entire semester. must take
see above

While this course is an SBS elective, I almost feel like it should be mandatory given how relevant the information is to so many areas of public health. My understanding of upstream determinants of mental health is so much more robust thanks to the readings, lectures/class discussions, and assignments. I would recommend the course to any student interested in mental health.

I would recommend this course to all students. You will learn about a broad range of mental health and illness topics, with a focus on population-level epidemiology, challenges, and solutions. The lectures are engaging, and Megan is truly a wonderful teacher who takes the time to highlight current news events and their applicability to our learning objectives and topics. This course will help apply what you learn in the readings, lectures, and classroom to the "real world" through interesting assignments (e.g. policy brief for the governor elect of CT, panel presentation and discussion, mental illness and public health program solution).

This course addresses influencing factors of mental health and illness with a specific focus on mediators and moderators of mental illness. It employs practical application of materials through assignments including political briefs and presentations. The final consists of a paper where students analyze and evaluate a mental illness and a public health program that addresses said mental illness.

The course provides an opportunity to do a deep dive into a specific population and how that population handles mental health treatment. I would recommend it for any student interested in exploring mental health or in thinking critically about solving issues around mental health care access.
I enjoyed this course a lot. I recommend it to everyone who are interested in mental health.
Great course, would highly recommend.

This course gave an overview of the social and cultural barriers of mental health that are faced from the time that we are in the womb until adulthood. I would highly recommend this as a mental health class to any student!

AP-
Hands down the highlight of my fall semester. Best organized course. Best professor and TF. Best lectures. Would highly recommend any lunch talk/course/mixer involving Megan Smith and/or Adam Viera.
As someone who entered the course without a particular affinity for SBS courses, I would highly recommend this class to ALL MPH students. It offered me tools for understanding mental health and the world around me.
Highly recommend! You leave with a much better perspective of mental health in our society.
Interesting course on mental issues in public health.  Well taught with average workload.

This class is an important and relevant issue that all students should take. Having it be grounded in research makes it academic, complementing the narrative side of mental health. The knowledge that you will gain from this class will be helpful for the rest of your life. It will help how you see everyday people, politics, and future research/studies.
I would recommend.

Wonderful course, relevant literature and engaging conversations.  The student presentations were among the best that I've seen in my time at YSPH and forcing students into a 4-minute time window was helpful in ensuring presentations were concise (like mini Ted talks)
AP: Highly recommended, I think this will be very useful in my career in public health/as a physician in articulating arguments to influence health policy using evidence.

Dr. Smith is a fantastic professor and is able to explain mental disorders across the lifespan, specifically those directly associated with cultural norms and expectations. For this class specifically, you are in charge of your learning outcomes. The more effort you put into the material, the higher your learning outcomes will be.
Would highly recommend this class to another student
You will learn about the social and cultural factors of mental health in a very deliberate way. I would most definitely recommend it to another student because Professor Smith is simply wonderful.

I would recommend this course for students who are interested in the social and cultural determinants of various mental health problems across different subpopulations. A different topic in mental health is covered every week, although this does kind of suck when the class discussions get very interesting because it felt like we were often short on time. However, I appreciate the diversity of topics covered, and I would recommend it for anyone looking for a public health class that talks about important problems our society faces in mental health.

Great course! I highly recommend to anyone who wants to think more deeply and holistically about the issues surrounding mental illness. However, this is not a course that dives into mental illness from an etiological or biological perspective. The workload was very manageable (with the exception of the readings-- there were way too many and I think this became counterproductive due to the fact that no one would seriously analyze all 8 articles). This class forced me to think critically and in a deeper way and really enhanced my semester!
Really interesting course. Would recommend taking in Year 1
Yes - amazing course to think about and develop perspectives for mental health reforms in our country and abroad. Good practice in developing policies.
great class, would recommend!
This course is great for understanding how different factors influence the epidemiology of mental health disorders and how policies effect mental health disorders. I would definitely recommend it.
